title: I think I have a good memory but I'm not that good at remembering mathematics theories and formulas. Why is this and what should I do? - Quora

response.answer_text: Formulas and theorems are just the conclusions of derivations. They aren’t supposed to be memorized. If you understand how something works, you can derive for yourself what the pattern is and then formalize it. Your formalization can look different from the formula, but it’s correct as long as they are equivalent so they give the same results. If you can’t derive the pattern or if your pattern gives different results from the pattern in the problem, you should go back and make sure you understand the concepts of what you’re studying or rethink those concepts from a different perspective, and then try again.

Trust your mind to do the remembering for you. For your part, shift your focus from remembering to understanding, and everything will come together. It may take a little time, but don't worry--brains are very good at remembering things when we don't get in their way. Just stick with it, focusing on understanding the material; no need to micro-manage your brain.
